item.title: How to correctly analyze reaction time (RT) data
item.description:
This is a very, very important topic given the widespread usage of reaction times in psychology. Most of the time, we analyze it as a regular variable, using traditional models such as linear models, ANOVAs etc. The problem is that these models assume that the RT is normally distributed, which is false. This leads us to adjustements like outliers removal or log-transformation, distorting the data because of our non-appropriate models.

The good news is, it’s very easy to use better models, that account for the non-normal distribution of RT. And these alternatives are beautifully presented by Jonas K. Lindeløv in the guide below:

👉 https://lindeloev.github.io/shiny-rt/ 👈

It is a must-read for all psychologist. Do check-it out!!

Thanks for reading! Do not hesitate to tweet and share this post, and leave a comment below 🤗

item.title: In defence of the 95% CI
item.description:
TLDR; BayestestR currently uses a 89% threshold by default for Credible Intervals (CI). Should we change that? If so, by what? Join the discussion here.

Magical numbers, or conventional thresholds, have bad press in statistics, and there are many of them. For instance, .05 (for the p-value), or the 95% range for the Confidence Interval (CI). Indeed, why 95 and not 94 or 90?

👉 Read my complete post on the easystats’ blog 👈
